texts.definition: Characters in games that are under players' direct control or represent the players role in the gameplay.
markups: <style="Definition">Characters in games that are under players' direct control or represent the players role in the gameplay.</style>

While fictional individuals in games may have abstract qualities that make them into characters, not all are controlled by players. Those that are become <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style>.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

The introduction of <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> was one of the design features that create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> from <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Miniature%20Games">Miniature Games</link></style>. This is found in most <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ars%20Magica">Ars Magica</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Basic%20Role-Playing">Basic Role-Playing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Roleplay">Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay</link></style> but <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Universalis">Universalis</link></style> is an exception of the general rule. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/1942%20%E2%80%93%20Noen%20%C3%A5%20stole%20p%C3%A5">1942 – Noen å stole på</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragonbane">Dragonbane</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trenne%20Byar">Trenne Byar</link></style>, also have <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> but in these case the players enact them not only by saying what they are doing but by physically enacting the actions and by embodying the characters with their own bodies. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based varieties</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Entropia%20Universe">Entropia Universe</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dark%20Age%20of%20Camelot">Dark Age of Camelot</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/DragonMud">DragonMud</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ultima%20Online">Ultima Online</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Witcher%20series">Witcher series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> do likewise but in some cases, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20series">The Elder Scrolls series</link></style> also allow partial or complete control of companions of the <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Borderlands">Borderlands</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style> show how a form of <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> can exist in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> by letting players develop characters by gaining experience points that can be used to unlock new abilities.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> are created by either letting players control <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> - this can be considered <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> since to outsiders the players and <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> share goals even if the players themselves may not identify with the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> but rather the overarching goals of a game. In the case where players may adopt the goals of the game rather than the goals of the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, game designers may consider if it can be sufficient to only use <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> (possibly together with a few characteristics such as <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>) instead of <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> and <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> in a game design. It is often a design goal to let players feel <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Identification">Identification</link></style> with <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style>; <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style> are ways of making this more likely. Another common design goal is to use <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> to make players experience <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Engrossment">Character Engrossment</link></style>. A supporting goal for this can be that players should as much as possible know and experience the same things as their <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style>, that is provide a <style="Link"><link="player-character-awareness-consistency">Player/Character Awareness Consistency</link></style> - the challenges to this typically revolve around interface issues and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character/Player%20Cognitive%20Imbalance">Character/Player Cognitive Imbalance</link></style>.

Games typically make <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> more functionally powerful than other <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. This is quite commonly done through <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> to match any exceptional status they may have through the narration.

In <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style> can consist solely of <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> but can in all types of games contain <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>. Regardless of which type of games <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style> exist in, they modulate <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> by defining relations for them and quite likely also <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style>.

There are several design choices that become more relevant when players are to control Characters. First, they may be Player-Created Characters, letting players have influence on their Equipment and Companions. Player Characters are open for players to add Player Defined Goals that the Characters also have, but game designs can encourage or require this as well as part of creating the Player Characters. Second, should they fate be set through Predetermined Story Structures or should they have an Open Destiny, and, related to this, should their exist Character Defining Actions during the gameplay and should players be supported in having a Player-Planned Development for the Characters (and this can be regardless if they can actual influence the development). More specifically, while some Game Items may be Transferable Items in a game, other may not be transferable to other Characters than Player Characters (e.g. Dragon Age II has special Equipment that only the Player Character Hawke can use). It is quite common for Player Characters to have Secret Goals, and this can spontaneously occur since players can add such goals as Player Defined Goals which the Player Characters also have.

For games that wish to support <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style>, how to handle the <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> need to be considered, especially for <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> purposes.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>

<style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style> heavily modulate the design options possible for <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style>. This since the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> need to be based on the actual players that will enact them so that their appearances, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> do not break <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.

Interfaces can easily make player perceive <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> differently from their <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> or <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, thereby lessening the <style="Link"><link="player-character-awareness-consistency">Player/Character Awareness Consistency</link></style> and affecting what players make their <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> do. While <style="Link"><link="first-person-views">First-Person Views</link></style> may be the view point that caused the least of this inconsistency, <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="vision-modes">Vision Modes</link></style> can still make it present and the imbalance caused by <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character/Player%20Cognitive%20Imbalance">Character/Player Cognitive Imbalance</link></style> is independent of this type of imbalance.
<style="H3">Narration Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> are typically important to <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, but not necessary the whole design of them but rather the events that they will be part of and perhaps some defining characteristics they possess. This is due to often wanting players themselves to have some control of the design of the <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> - see the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style> for a typical example of this type of design. <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> can also help create <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> during gameplay.

<style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> may be difficult to guarantee with this pattern since having <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> let players have significant control in how individual <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> behave in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. This can however be controlled by having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, and then the added details players can provide can support <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> provides players with a <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> in which to interact with <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and is more likely to make the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> control be perceived as <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>. Unlike other types of <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> form a natural starting point to begin <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> and lets them have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> in how to do this, including engaging in <style="Link"><link="gossip">Gossip</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>. While letting players control <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> can give them a focus to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Engrossment">Character Engrossment</link></style> and thereby <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> during gameplay, this attachment can be cut if the game provides <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> whose effect on <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> were not wanted by the players and not perceivable beforehand.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character/Player%20Cognitive%20Imbalance">Character/Player Cognitive Imbalance</link></style> may easily arise in games with <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> due to the design of a game's interface and the difference in knowledge players and their <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> have regarding the game state or <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>. Note that this is not only a case of players knowing more than the [[Player Characters], it may be the other way around or they may have access to different knowledge. While this <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character/Player%20Cognitive%20Imbalance">Character/Player Cognitive Imbalance</link></style> is not typically effects of design choices directly related to <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style>, the imbalance does affect how <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> manifest in a game and therefore needs to be considered when considering <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style>.

Give that players often provide <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> with various peculiarity in their behaviors and expressions, it may be difficult to maintain a <style="Link"><link="possibility-anonymity">Possibility of Anonymity</link></style> unless games have completely <style="Link"><link="mediated-gameplay">Mediated Gameplay</link></style>.

Since <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> contain the game state values most likely to affect players' valorization, the <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> of the <style="CurrentLink">Player Characters</style> of <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style> may can be difficult to combine with <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>.
